abstract: Tuesday’s reading list includes thoughts on Google versus Apple and another possible competitor for both of them.
snippet: Tuesday’s reading list includes thoughts on Google versus Apple and another possible competitor for both of them.
lead_paragraph: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times recommend articles on the cellphone wars and how Twitter may be eating its own dog food.  And just for fun: another robot video and a way to create a parody of the Google search ads.

abstract: Demand for the iPad in the United States, with 500,000 sold in one week, has exceeded expectations, Apple said.
snippet: Demand for the iPad in the United States, with 500,000 sold in one week, has exceeded expectations, Apple said.
lead_paragraph: Responding to strong demand in the United States for its iPad, Apple said Wednesday that it would delay the worldwide release of the tablet computer for a month.

headline.main: Apple Delays Global Release of iPad
headline.print_headline: High U.S. Demand for iPad Delays Its Debut Abroad

abstract: The company said that it would delay international sales of the iPad for a month, citing “surprisingly strong U.S. demand.”
snippet: The company said that it would delay international sales of the iPad for a month, citing “surprisingly strong U.S. demand.”
lead_paragraph: People outside the United States who are hoping to get their hands on an iPad will have to wait a little longer than they expected. Apple said on Wednesday that it was delaying international sales of the iPad for at least a month because of  strong demand at home.

abstract: With Apple selling millions of iPhones, it was perhaps inevitable that a cottage industry of iPhone repair shops would follow.
snippet: With Apple selling millions of iPhones, it was perhaps inevitable that a cottage industry of iPhone repair shops would follow.
lead_paragraph: Brendan McElroy’s living room in an apartment on the top floor of an East Village walk-up is crowded with anxious patients, each one jiggling a knee, or gnawing on a fingernail or lip.

headline.main: How to Fix Your iPhone (the Unofficial Edition)
headline.print_headline: How to Fix Your iPhone (the Unauthorized Edition)

abstract: Now that hard-drive video storage has become so cheap, taped memories can be moved into a computer with a minimum of fuss.
snippet: Now that hard-drive video storage has become so cheap, taped memories can be moved into a computer with a minimum of fuss.
lead_paragraph: It started with a call from Steve Jobs.

headline.main: Moving Taped Past to Hard-Drive Future
headline.print_headline: The Past, From Tape To Drive

abstract: Tensions between Twitter and its developers and an interview with Dean Kamen, the inventor of the Segway, top this week’s Tech Talk podcast.
snippet: Tensions between Twitter and its developers and an interview with Dean Kamen, the inventor of the Segway, top this week’s Tech Talk podcast.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein finds out why Twitter app developers are worried. She speaks with Claire Cain Miller, The Times technology reporter who covers Twitter, about the company’s moves toward building its own tools for the microblogging service, and the concerns among developers who fear that Twitter might turn into a competitor. Independent developers have created some 70,000 apps that let users do things like track messages on cellphones, monitor multiple Twitter accounts, shorten link addresses and post photos on the service.Dean Kamen, inventor of the Segway, is also a strong advocate of promoting science and technology education. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Mr. Kamen about his own early inspirations and about the nonprofit group he founded to encourage interest in these fields among the young. The organization, called First  (For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology), holds its 19th annual championship, with competitions in robotics, gaming and Lego construction, April 15-17 at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta.You might expect your brand new computer to have a clean hard drive, only to find programs installed on it that you didn’t ask for, or trial versions of software that pester you to buy the full version or sign up for a service. There is a name for that, as Pedro Rafael Rosado explains in his regularly featured audio essay on tech terms.Also on the show, Ms. Biersdorfer rounds up tech news of the week, including updates for the Google Docs service, a new fleet of MacBook Pro laptops from Apple; Neflix streaming movies via Wii game consoles; and prepackaged movies on portable Seagate drives. And if you can’t wait for baseball season to start, her tech tip of the week can help you get set: MySportsCal lets you download your favorite team’s schedule right into your Outlook, iCal or Google calendar.
